instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good‚Äù and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
I have this board which power cycles n <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - power cycles
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> - power cycles
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - power cycles
<SIGNAL>SMC_S4_WAKESRC_EN</SIGNAL> - power cycles
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.3V

There is no visible liquid around SMC.
Also, how do you test these boards without the attached battery? Is there the easiest way than yanking the battery connector?

Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
This board should start by itself on charger only.

First try to start in SMC bypass mode; to discard any SMC sensor issue.
Check for short on all secondary voltages.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Thanks, 2informaticos

SMC bypass power cycles as well, with the fan turning on and off as it cycles.

Probed for shorts around all coils and filtering caps. I haven't found any. 
The lowest reading I've got was around these coils, which is expected I believe.
L7630 - <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_REG_R</SIGNAL> - 80Ohms
L7430 - <SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> - 200Ohms

In SMC bypass mode, the heat signature (3* higher than ambient temp) is pulsing around <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> - BCM15700. Not sure how it is related unless water corroded some pins underneath the BGA
[ATTACH]59280[/ATTACH][ATTACH]59279[/ATTACH]

SMC and battery charger are warming up, even if no battery is connected
[ATTACH]59281[/ATTACH]

Haven't run it through ultrasonic yet, perhaps should go on that now.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals and secondary voltages.

<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> works all the time charger is connected; no matters battery is present, or not.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Thanks

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> - pulsing - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> - pulsing - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - pulsing - 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 5V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 5V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>- 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3RSS0_CAMERA</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V

<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 1.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 1.5V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> - 1.05V

<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>  - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>  - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - Pulsing 3.3V - 3.42V

<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PHASE1</SIGNAL>-3 - Pulsing 1.6V

Let me know if any other voltages you may need?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Try it with both charger and battery connected.
Just put the board in the chassis and connect battery, no other devices...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
When the board only is attached to the battery, with a connected charger I get quarter fan spin. 1.28A is drawn to charge the battery. Went like this for a couple of minutes and no more fan spin.

When only on battery no fan spin

When only on the charger - 20mA drawn

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and their traces.
Try known good BIOS file, clean ME.

No liquid sign, but any history available?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message: Yeah apparently was dropped in a puddle of water. But it seems like it was wiped off. No discoloration marks on the board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message: I suppose you are using an original 85watts charger , also you can try to get a charged battery , that is if you are using an after market charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
You can have accumulated crap under BGA chips.
Heat them with quality flux, just in case...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message:
Hi [USER=1946]@huzeafa[/USER] yes 80W charger on bench supply.
[USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER], any suggestions of which GBA chips to reflow? I ran it through the ultrasonic and reflowed  <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> with no luck.

Next will hit SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message: PCH and SMC should be first to try...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> power cycles
threads.message: No luck here. Will have to give up.
